Run. Hide. Fight. Surviving an Active Shooter Event

It may feel like just another day on campus. But occasionally, life feels more like an action movie than reality. The authorities are working hard to protect you, and to protect our university community. But sometimes bad people do bad things. Their motivations are different. The warning signs may vary, but the devastating effects are the same. Unfortunately, you need to be prepared for the worst. If you are to ever find yourself in the middle of a hostile intruder event, your survival may depend on whether or not you have a plan. The plan doesn’t have to be complicated.

There are three things you can do to make a difference. Run. Hide. Fight.

( Student: There’s a shooter in Valk! ) First and foremost, if you can get out safely – get out. If it is safe to do so, always try and escape or evacuate, even when others insist on staying. Remember what’s important – you, not your stuff. Leave your belongings behind and try to find a way to get out safely. Encourage others to leave with you, but don’t let them slow you down with indecision. Trying to get yourself out of harm’s way needs to be your number one priority. Once you are in an area of safety, try to prevent others from walking into the danger zone and call University Police. If you can’t get out safely, you need to find a place to hide. Act quickly and quietly. Try to secure your hiding place the best you can. Turn out lights, and if possible, remember to lock doors. Silence your ringer to vibration mode on your cell phone. If you can’t find a safe room or closet, try to conceal yourself behind large objects that may protect you. Do your best to remain quiet and calm. (Professor giving a lesson) As a last resort, if your life is at risk, whether you’re alone or working together as a group – FIGHT. Act with aggression. Improvise weapons. Overwhelm them. (Plan is being devised by professor). Commit to taking the intruder down no matter what. Your life depends on it. Try to be aware of your environment, and always have an exit plan. Know that in an incident like this, victims are generally chosen randomly. The event is unpredictable, and may evolve quickly. The first responders on the scene are not there to evacuate or attend to the injured. They are well trained and are there to stop the intruder. Your actions can make a difference for your safety and survival. Be aware and be prepared. If you ever find yourself faced with a hostile intruder, there are three key things you need to remember to survive: Run. Hide. Fight.

One of the worst tragedies any campus could face, would be that of an active shooter or hostile intruder. Events in recent history have taught us that we can’t afford to think that it’ll never happen here or that it can’t happen here. We have to prepare for what to expect. We have options. When it comes to response options for a hostile intruder situation, arguably, three of the most important words are run, hide, and fight. There are three more just as important words to learn and remember: secure, evaluate, and act.

In any critical event, one of the first and foremost important tasks is to protect yourself and those around you, as much as possible. Secure your immediate area. Make it safe for yourself and anyone else with you. Get out of sight, lock doors, close blinds, turn off external sources of noise, look and identify items that you can use to defend yourself if you need to. If you’re in a hallway, move to the next open and available room and get out of sight. If you’re in a bathroom, get out of view by raising your feet off the ground or standing on a toilet. Remember, in most hostile intruder situations, if you’re out of sight, you’re out of mind. If a potentially bad person can’t see you, the possibility of them inflicting harm on you is greatly diminished

Evaluate your environment. After you have secured your immediate area, gather as much information as you can concerning what is going on. Listen for gunshots, screams, commotion, and check for information contained in the emergency alerts. If you’re not hearing any discerning noises, you may not be in immediate danger. If you have time, look for any comments on social media or texts from others who may be involved. Are you in a safe location? Or is there safer cover elsewhere? What exits are available? And are there other ways out of the building? If the fire alarm system is activated, take extra care in evaluating your surroundings. If you don’t see smoke or fire, or smell anything burning, this may be a distraction technique used by the intruder to bring you in to the line of fire. Take note of your evacuation routes, however, and only exit if you feel you’re in danger from an actual fire. Understand that initial information is going to be limited. You may not have much to go by, but it is important to properly evaluate factual information, not rumors or conclusions. Evaluate social media with caution. Official information will come from trusted sources, specifically university sites.

Act. Decide on a plan of action. After you evaluate the information you have, make a plan and carry it out with conviction. After you evaluate what information you have available, your act may be run. If a hostile intruder is in your area and it is safe to do so, identify a safe route to exit away from any possible threats, and get out. Do not put yourself in any unnecessary danger or worry about taking belongings with you. If you cannot get out safely, your act may be hide or shelter in place. Reinforce your secured area. Use tables, chairs, filing cabinets, any heavy object that may impede an intruder’s entry. Make sure doors are locked, turn out lights, and take cover out of sight. During the evaluation process, if you determine your building is away from the event or there is no information indicating that you are in direct danger, hide or shelter in place. If you’re not hearing gunshots, screams, or other noises indicating that the threat is in your building, this might be your best action. As a last resort, only if your life is in immediate danger, fight. Don’t go looking for a fight or feel it’s your obligation. Your obligation is to live. When face-to-face with a hostile intruder, it’s your life or theirs. Act with aggression and never, never give up. Your actions should be delivered and done with intent. Any action you take is a step at protecting your life and those around you. Unfortunately we cannot stop violent acts from happening.

There is no way to predict when or where, the date, or time a hostile intruder event will happen. We can, however, prepare ourselves both mentally and physically by knowing our response options. Immediate actions save lives. Secure, evaluate, act.

Several recent and very tragic incidents in public spaces around the country have heightened our concern and awareness about what steps to take if ever confronted with a hostile intruder situation. Whether you’re face-to-face with a gunman or you’re faced with information indicating that a hostile intruder event is occurring in your area, you are pressed with a need to do something. Knowing that you have options on how to respond and what those options are is an important step in surviving any hostile intruder event. If there is a shooter or some form of verified hostile act taking place in the building you’re in, immediately secure your area. Evaluate what information you have available and formulate a plan of action. Quickly determine the most reasonable way to protect your own life and those around you.

Act. Decide on a plan of action. After you evaluate the information you have, make a plan and carry it out with conviction. If it is determined there is a hostile act where people are being injured or killed in or around where you are, your action may be to run. First and foremost, if you can get out, get out. Your safety is your first priority. And the measure of your success is that you survive. Part of your evaluation should consider whether or not you can exit safely and whether or not clear access to exit points are available. If you can do so safely, observe your surrounding area; hallways, stairwells, windows, potential hiding places, available weapons, and exit locations. Consider what evacuation routes are available and plan your exit carefully. Evacuate away from the location of the intruder. Don’t run into the line of fire. And don’t feel you must stop the intruder.

When running from an active shooter, stay close to walls and take cover as necessary, to reassess the situation. Continue to move quickly and with determination until you reach safety. Take as many people with you as you can and try to prevent others from entering the danger zone. Leave your belongings behind and evacuate whether others agree to or not. Communicate to others where you are going and if necessary, how to get there. Your evacuation plan should provide quick and easy access to exit points and stairwells, include routes away from any sounds of gunshots or acts of violence, and include a familiar off-campus safe area. You best option for a safe area is a location somewhere off-campus that you’re familiar with.

When considering your exit from the building, don’t just consider hallways and stairwells. Breaking a window and exiting that way might be a good option, especially from the first floor. If you have a book bag or backpack with several books, wear it for added protection in a manner that puts it between you and the intruder. Continually monitor your environment and what information you have available. When getting information from social media sites, remember, that not all information on social media is reliable. The most accurate and factual information will come from official university sources. When you feel it is safe to do so, notify University Police. Give them your location, number of people with you, any injuries, and any information pertaining to the intruder that you may know.

When evacuating a building or area due to a hostile violent act, you are ultimately responsible for any decisions and actions regarding your own personal safety. By seeking shelter in another campus building, you may unintentionally be putting yourself back into harm’s way. If you determine that run is your best course of action, it is best to quickly and safely work your way to an off-campus, safe area. When determining your options, there are many things to consider. But is important to evaluate what information you actually have. What you hear and see, combined with any information obtained through external sources, is the best way to help decide what to do next. Remember, your action or actions are what will make a difference on how you survive a hostile intruder event. You have options.

When it comes to how we response to intruder event rather it’s individually or in a group. Immediate actions save lives. It’s important to know what options we have in by planning and becoming familiar with response techniques we can minimize the time it takes to react. The time it takes decide on an action can have a drastic impact on any critical event. When determining your options there are many things to consider but it’s important to evaluate what information you actually have information may be limited initially. What you hear and see combined with info from external sources will help you decide what to do next.

If there is a shooter or some form of verified hostile acts taking place in the building you are in immediately secure your area, evaluate any information you have available, and make a plan of action. Quickly determine how to protect your own life and others around you. If you are hearing gun shots, explosions, screams, or seeing anything that might indicate a hostile event is taking place where you are located your action may be to HIDE or shelter in place. If you cannot safely get out and an evaluation is not possible secure your location and find shelter. If you not sure what you hearing is gun fire trust your intuition. If it sounds if those it could be a gun react if it is every second counts. Observe your surrounding area and identify potential to hide. Lock & barricade doors with furniture to make it harder for an entry. Stack chairs, desk, and tables or other thing in front of door or entry way. Don’t worry about damaging property inside the classroom do whatever it takes to block the door. The idea is to put something between you and the intruder. Make it as difficult as possible for them to get in. If you have time use a chair or belt to secure the door or wrap your belt or back bag strap around door close arm or wedge a door stopper. You may need to be creative but don’t just give up. Some classrooms are equipped with a lock/unlock button that electronically locks all access doors from one location within the room. This button is usually located in the instructor station and will secure the doors to that room only. If you room has a lock out button be sure to activate it prior to sheltering. Turn off lights, close blinds, and get out of sight. Hide behind large objects- concrete walls, filling cabinets, heavy desks. Keep oneself quiet, calm, and out of view. Turn off your ringer or any sources of external noise. Note: Even the vibration mode on your phone can sometimes be heard and give away your location. Once you have taken shelter start coming up with a plan and how you will respond if the intruder is determined to get into your safe area. Look for any objects that can be used as a weapon in case you have to defend yourself. Familiarize yourself with hallways, stair wells, windows, and other possible ways to exit if the option to run becomes available. Make sure you know exit routes and are aware of your surroundings. If in the hallway or open area with a nearby exit- Run! If you do not have access to an exit find nearest shelter or place. Move away from the commotion. If you can see the intruder move in the opposite direction. If you have a book bag, wear a book bag with books for added protection in a manner between you and the intruder. When you feel it is safe notify university police. Give them your location, number of people your with, any injuries, and intruder info may know. Campus alert system or intercom addressing the crisis secure yourself. Information only situation.

If the activity is not where you are recommend hide or shelter in place. If you are not directly involved in the incident hear or see any commotion in your area no gun shots, sounds of screaming or site of people running and nothing is indicating you’re in immediate danger you should shelter in place. Immediately lock your doors, turn out lights, and secure your area. Activate the lockout button prior to sheltering. Begin identifying strategies on best how to protect yourself or defend yourself if events change. Continually monitor your environment for additional information. Evaluate social media with caution. Evaluate social media with caution. Note: Not information on social media is reliable. The most accurate and factual information will come from university sources. If you are outside and receive information that a hostile intruder event has taken place on campus, immediately evacuate on an off campus safe area.

Avoid seeking shelter in another building, you may unintentionally put yourself in harms way.

Do not return to campus until authorities say it is safe to do so. How you response to a threaten situation is ultimately your decision. Northwest always want you to always be prepared and never think that it can’t happen here. Remember when determining your options evaluate what information you actually have what you hear and see combined with any valid information through external sources is the best way to decide what to do next. If you receive updates regarding police response or the last location of the intruder this information may help you plan and make decisions to just continue to shelter in place evacuate or prepare for something else that may soon to happen. If immediate medical attention is needed notify university police when you feel it is safe. Give them your location, amount of people with you, and number of people injured and types of injuries. Understand information around this time may be limited and shelter in place action may last several hours. Know and trust authorities are working diligently to the situation and store safety onto our campus. Wait for police to come to you. They will provide attention, aid, or direction as soon as possible. Your first priority in any event is your safety how you prepare now will determine how you respond later. Immediate actions saves lives.

Your university police department works hard every day to ensure our campus is safe and free from any threats of harm. Although it is very unlikely, there is a possibility that you could be faced with a situation in which an armed or hostile intruder is threatening your safety or the safety of those around you. Should the unthinkable happen on our campus, you must know how to react to lessen the impact and help protect yourself and others. A lot of questions are created by hostile acts. Why here? Why now? Why me? There may or may not be an intended target. But one thing is certain, their intent. They are there to kill you and those around you. They don’t care who you are, what you do, or what you’re going through. Their mindset is simple; they want to kill as many innocent and unarmed people as they can. If you ever become involved in a hostile intruder situation, you may not have much time to make a decision. You may not have the options to run or hide. If you are faced with an immediate threat to your life and there is no chance for your escape, fight may be your immediate action and your only option. You may have no other choice but to fight for your life.

It’s difficult to say how any of us will react if faced with a hostile intruder, but now is the time to put yourself into that terrifying position and try to imagine and plan for what you would do. What do you feel you are capable of doing? And what measures are you prepared to take to stay alive? Each of us needs to identify a reason to live. The fight in “Run, Hide, Fight” is not for everyone. Not everyone is prepared, capable, or confident enough to confront an aggressor. Confronting a hostile intruder is undoubtedly the most stressful and dangerous situation you may ever be faced with. Only confront a hostile intruder if it is obvious that you are in immediate danger and there is no other way to run from or hide in the area you are in. And never leave a safe or secure area to search for or engage an intruder.

When considering options for fighting back, we must first understand that for hostile intruder situations there’s two types of fight, prepared and immediate. With a prepared position, you have the ability to prepare yourself and your location for what is coming. You are aware of a critical situation unfolding in your immediate area and have the ability to formulate plans, fortify your location, look for ways to protect yourself, and prepare a defense. In a prepared response, you will know something is coming. You may hear the sound of gunfire, people screaming, or you might see people running. It will be evident that something out of the ordinary is happening in your building.

If the intruder is close to your location, you will most likely be able to tell if they are getting closer or not. This is your cue to take immediate action. If you have time and are able, as quickly as you can, secure your location as best as possible. Evaluate everything that you hear, see, or smell. At this point, every second counts. Time is not on your side. You must act and act quickly. Plan and coordinate your actions with others around you. Start identifying and gathering items that you can use to protect yourself. Every room has something that can be used as an improvised weapon or tool to distract and defend yourself, if needed.

As previously discussed in detail, your actions may be to run or hide. But if there’s no time or way to evacuate or to keep the intruder out of the room you are in, it may come down to a fight for your life. It’s your decision. Fight is a last resort survival measure. There are three important roles when it comes to fight; fight, distract, hide. The fight role requires individuals who are ready, both mentally and physically, to commit to an aggressive action and are willing to confront an intruder from a defensive position. These individuals have the needed mindset, skill level, and necessary drive to survive, and will do what it takes to overwhelm the intruder. The distract role requires individuals who will provide a distraction by drawing the attention to themselves once an intruder has gained entry into your safe area. These individuals are critical to those in the fight role. In the hide role, individuals who have no other obligation or are unable to fight or distract should attempt to get out of sight and away from the danger zone. These individuals should help others take shelter as far from the fight area as possible and follow the guidelines of hide.

The number of people utilized in the fight role varies; it can be as many as an entire class or as few as one, depending on the area and resources available. Individuals identified as fulfilling the fight role should locate a defensive position, either at a doorway, entryway, or other area they see fit. Based on the size and layout of the room, determine an attack point that gives you quick access to the intruder, but also provides the opportunity to be slightly out of sight. This could be on one side of the door, both sides, or even a blind alcove. Preferably two or three individuals should line up together against the wall and try to stay out of view as much as possible, crouch down below the line of sight, and be prepared to lunge at the first sight of the intruder or the intruder’s weapon. Speed is essential when executing your attack. You should coordinate your actions in attempt to overwhelm the intruder.

The first person should go for control of the weapon. Move quickly and grab the barrel or grab the hands. The idea is to control the weapon and where it is pointing. Don’t let the intruder have the ability to move the gun around freely. If the weapon gets dislodged or becomes free, slide it away from the intruder and try to hold their hands down and limit their movement. Without sacrificing your stability, place as much of your body weight as you can on their head or upper torso and keep them down. The second person should go directly for the knees. Use your entire body weight and drive into the side of the joint and wrap arms, as tight as you can, around both legs. Don’t be concerned with hurting them. Your job is to stop their movement and bring them to the ground. Continue holding their legs, even after they have fallen. Additional persons individuals involved with the attack should keep the intruder pinned to the ground or help control their movement. Use what means are at your disposal to keep the intruder contained and don’t let up until police arrive, even if they say they give up.

The individuals fulfilling the distract role are doing just that; they are distracting the intruder’s attention away from those in the fight and hide roles. The individuals providing the distraction should be close enough to the danger zone that they are visible by the intruder, but yet far enough away that they’re not obstructing or giving away the position of those fighting. The distraction is an important task which helps ensure the success of those individuals preparing to fight. Those participating in the distract role should locate items they can throw at the intruder to disrupt their vision and their plan, and put them on the defensive. Once the intruder becomes visible, those providing the distraction should begin yelling, running in the opposite direction, and throwing objects at the intruder. By yelling, we are drawing the intruder’s immediate attention. By moving, we are making ourselves a harder target and keeping the intruder fixated away from the attack. By throwing objects, we are impacting the intruder’s vision and making them react to us.

Once the intruder has been confronted, if you are able, help those involved in the fight by helping to overwhelm the intruder or keep them pinned down and contained. Restrict their movement as much as possible and hold them down until police arrive. Safety says, anyone not involved in the two previous roles should get out of the immediate danger zone and find a place to hide. Try to find a location away from the activity and shelter as best as possible. Use large objects such as desks, filing cabinets, or concrete walls to conceal yourself from the intruder’s view and help others around you remain quiet and calm. Never stop planning. Look around for any items or objects you can use as potential weapons, just in case you end up having to defend yourself. Never just give up and become a passive target. If worse comes to worse, and you end up being confronted by the intruder, plan what you might do next. If the opportunity to run becomes available, take it and get out. Have an idea of how you might exit and where you will go.

If a hostile intruder surprises you or an aggressive situation escalates in your presence, you will be forced to act as quickly as possible. You may not have the options to run or hide, and resources available may be limited. If you are in close proximity to the hostile intruder, in the line of fire, or in a room where an exit is not an option, quick action can save your life. Once you recognize that there is a weapon in the room or someone is committing a hostile act where you’re located, it is imperative that you take immediate action. Start throwing objects, anything you can get your hands on; cell phones, laptops, book bags, pencils, pens, chairs, anything that can disrupt the intruder’s vision. Yell “gun” or “intruder” to help alert others of the danger, and charge the aggressor without delay. This is an immediate fight for your life. Follow the same attack methods as previously described. Go for control of the weapon, take out the knees, swarm and overwhelm the intruder with superior numbers. Disarm and incapacitate the intruder any way you can. Take them down and hold them until police arrive. When it is safe to do so, have someone notify University Police and inform them of the situation. If the weapon becomes dislodged and is lying in the open, place a trash-can or other object over it for safety, as long as the intruder is contained. Someone should guard it and not let anyone pick it up, unless it becomes necessary for your survival. Know that when police arrive, you may become mistaken for the intruder if you are holding a weapon.

Once you are confident that the intruder is securely contained, you may decide that other individuals in the room should begin evacuating. Have them exit the room quietly and quickly, with their hands over their heads and fingers spread open. Police are trained to respond immediately. Understand that police are not there to care for injured or evacuate people from the building. Their mission is to stop the intruder from harming other innocent people, as quickly as possible. When officers arrive, it’s important that you keep your hands visible at all times. Remain calm and expect to hear officers shouting orders and instructions to people for their safety. Put down any items you may have in your hands and avoid pointing or sudden movements. Always follow the commands of police officers as they arrive. Having a plan and a clear understanding of what options are available and what actions are needed will greatly increase our chances of survival, if we are ever faced with a hostile intruder situation. Now is the time to plan. Now is the time to ask yourself what measures you will go to to protect your life. What actions are you prepared to take if you find yourself face-to-face with a hostile intruder? What reason will you find to survive?

Kelsi:

Here we are in Office of Human Resources. As a new student employee, you are required to review and sign a confidentiality statement. The confidentiality statement is completed during the time initial employment verification and authorization paperwork is completed.

Jordan:

Confidentiality is important for all jobs on campus and is mandated by federal law. The Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act of 1974, as amended, is a federal law which provides that college and universities will maintain the confidentiality of student education records. Basically, the law says that no one outside the institution shall have access to your education records nor will the institution disclose any information from those records without your written consent. There are exceptions, of course, so certain personnel within the institution may see your records, including persons in an emergency in order to protect the health or safety of students or other persons.

Kelsi:

If you are a student employee of the University, you may have access to confidential records. Their confidentiality, use, and release are governed by FERPA. In general, all student information must be treated as confidential. Any questions about information released should be referred to your supervisor.

Now let’s look at some scenarios where confidentiality goes beyond student records. Each office or department will have their specific confidentiality policies.

At the Wellness Center a student employee, a receptionist, answers the phone.

Student Employee:

Good morning and thank you for calling the University Wellness Center. This is Ashleigh, how may I help you?

Parent:

Hello, my name is Jennifer Smith and I am calling in regards to my son Luke Smith. I received a bill from Northwest recently and there was a $80 charge from the Wellness Center. I need to speak with someone to figure out what the charges are for and why this wasn’t paid by our insurance.

Student Employee:

I understand, let me look and see if we have a copy of your son’s insurance on file. (Pause). It appears that we do not have your son’s insurance information on file. If you could either fax a copy of both sides of the card or have him bring a copy of his insurance card to the Wellness Center we will keep that on file for him.

Parent:

I appreciate your assistance; however, I would still like to know what the charges are for.

Student Employee:

I apologize for the inconvenience; however, If there are billing concerns, I would suggest that your son contact our office.

Parent:

The insurance is in my name and I pay the bills for my son to attend Northwest. Is there someone else that I can talk to?

Student Employee:

Would you please hold while I transfer you to my supervisor?

Parent:

Yes, thank you.

Supervisor:

Thank you for holding, this is Kelley, How may I assist you?

Parent:

This is extremely frustrating, The insurance is in my name and I pay the bills for my son to attend Northwest I don’t understand why you won’t tell me why he has been charged.

Supervisor:

I apologize for the frustration you are experiencing, however, HIPAA guidelines restrict us from communicating to anyone other than the patient regarding their visit or bill without their written consent. It is our responsibility to protect your son’s health information and our office from civil penalties. Please have your son call us to discuss his billing and/or signing an authorization to discuss his encounter with you.

Parent:

I will just have him call you.

University Police Department - Confidentiality –

The end of a study group session. Group leader says: ‘So let’s all meet next week at this same time’. The group disperses except for two.

Friend:

Hey Conner! How’s it going? Did you get your assignment finished for tomorrow? Hey by the way- you work for University Police right? What happened last night? There were cop cars outside my building and an ambulance at 4am!?

University Police student employee:

Yes, I work there but I had to sign a confidentiality agreement. That means I can’t talk about anything that happens at work outside of work.

Friend:

Oh, I don’t need to know the details, I just heard that someone was seriously hurt and wanted to make sure that they were ok.

Unviersity Police student employee:

That’s cool, I understand. I can always talk to my supervisor to find out if everyone was ok.

Friend:

Alright thanks.

Jordan:

If you have any questions regarding the confidentiality in your new position, make sure to ask your supervisor for clarification. Or if you have questions about the confidentiality statement you signed, contact the Office of Human Resources Management.

Kelsi:

As in all employment, Student Employment has its own policies and procedures. These policies and procedures define the program and provide consistency on how the program operates. It is critical that student employees become aware of all policies and procedures. This module will cover the main policies and procedures. The student employment handbook, which can be found on-line, covers everything in detail. Let’s start with employment eligibility.

Jordan:

Eligibility to work is based on a student’s enrollment status. Policies and procedures apply to both undergraduate and graduate students, excluding graduate assistants.

A student must be enrolled in a minimum of six credit hours during any trimester to be eligible for employment. If enrollment falls below six credit hours, employment will be discontinued.

Kelsi:

Summer enrollment requirements are the same. A student employee shall be enrolled in a minimum of six credit hours during the summer trimester regardless of the session(s) of enrollment.

Jordan:

A student is eligible to work during the University intersession providing registration is complete for a minimum of six credit hours for the next trimester of coursework. If pre-registration is not complete, a letter of intent to enroll from the student shall be delivered to Student Employment.

Kelsi:

Students may work with five or fewer credit hours only when it is their last trimester of coursework. In this case written notification must be given to Student Employment prior to the beginning of the trimester.

Kelsi:

Now let’s look at hour limitations. A student employee may work up to 20 hours per week during the fall and spring trimesters. It is a maximum of 20 hours regardless of the number of positions that a student holds in the Student Employment Program. ARAMARK and off campus positions not affiliated with the Student Employment Program are not considered for the 20 hour a week limit unless the employee is an international student.

Jordan:

A student may work up to 20 hours a week during the summer trimester session they are enrolled and up to 40 hours a week during the summer trimester sessions they are not enrolled if they have been enrolled in a total of six credit hours in any session of the summer trimester. A student may also work up to 40 hours a week or the equivalent of an eight-hour workday during official University breaks. At no time shall a student be allowed to work over 40 hours per week.

Kelsi:

According to the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, international students are limited to a maximum of 20 hours per week during the fall and spring trimester and a maximum of 40 hours per week during the summer trimester sessions they are not enrolled and during official University breaks, regardless of the number of employers.

A student employee is not allowed to work during scheduled class time.

Jordan:

Each department or office may have additional policies. Work with your supervisor for full understanding of policies and procedures specific in your position.

Kelsi:

Your schedule of work hours will vary depending which office or department you work for. Listen as a few supervisors explain how schedules work in their area.

Travis Stokes:

We understand that they are a student employee so they are a student first and so we work around their class schedules.

Stacy Stokes:

Our students work 8 to 5, Monday through Friday so we always have someone here in the office to answer the phones and cover the front counter. We set our schedule well in advance at the beginning of each trimester and it is set for the semester.

Glenn Morrow:

We are open several hours during the day. We have to have someone at the library services desk each of those hours and so it takes quite a bit of scheduling to accommodate that.

Danny Smith:

Student employees are allowed to work 20 hours a week or up to 20.

Jackie Loghry:

We allow them to set their own schedule as long as it’s when we’re open which is Monday through Friday, eight to five. They work ten hours each week in minimum two hour blocks a minimum of three days a week.

Linda Standerford:

Once I tell them how many hours they are going to work per week then I let them decide what hours they intend to work between the hours of eight to five, Monday through Friday.

Travis Stokes:

Yes. I do allow flexible schedules.

Linda Standerford:

Yes. We work with them. If they’ve got a week that they’ve got a lot of tests or maybe they’ve got a huge project we absolutely work with them.

Glenn Morrow:

We do in some areas of the library. Just as an example in the periodicals area we can allow some flexible schedules there. The majority of the areas, we can accommodate people except at the library services desk and we need someone there each hour as I’ve stated, so the flexibility is not so much there. That doesn’t mean they don’t have the option of switching out hours and trading hours but the desk has to be covered.

Linda Standerford:

Since our student employees are part time employees and generally they only work a few hours at a time, no, there is no need for a break.

Stacey Stokes:

We don’t have any scheduled breaks figured into the day but if someone were to need to go across the hall to the rest room, to get a snack, we will work with them on that but we don’t schedule that into the day.

Kelsi:

In summary, schedules are determined by the immediate supervisor and the student employee. Flexible schedules are offered to help accommodate students and their academic success. Any abuse of flexible scheduling may result in a discussion with the student employee.

Jordan:

A student shall be given a meal break if they are scheduled to work for an increment of eight hours or greater. Additional breaks shall be discussed with the supervisor. Remember, no breaks are paid.

Kelsi:

The university requires regular attendance and punctuality.

Linda Standerford:

We definitely expect good attendance and punctuality. That’s very important to the services we offer. So we do have a process in place if there is an employee that has issues with punctuality or tardiness.

Jackie Loghry:

We expect the students to work the 10 hours a week that they identify that they will be in the office so if they need to vary from those hours the policy is to contact the direct supervisor

Stacey Stokes:

When you are arriving to work you need to be here on time making certain that we have the front counter and the phone covered all times.

Travis Stokes:

We do expect our students to show up on time as a lot of our job is out in the field and if they tell us that they are going to be here at eight o’clock and they don’t show up until eight fifteen then we have just stood around waiting for them for fifteen minutes.

Linda Standerford:

If they need to be absent from their position I would expect them to let me know as soon as they can. If they are sick, obviously those are kind of last minute situations, but whenever possible we expect a notice as soon as we can get one.

Jackie Loghry:

They can call, email or text.

Stacy Stokes:

As soon as possible. Most advance notice that we can get is what we would prefer.

Travis Stokes:

If it’s a planned thing we would like at least a week’s notice for them.

Glenn Morrow:

We expect someone to be here and if they can’t be here and it’s something that is preplanned then we need to know in advance.

Danny Smith:

The best way to answer that is be responsible

Kelsi:

If prior communication is not feasible, communication shall be made as soon as possible. Excessive tardiness or absences may result in termination.

Jordan:

Now, we are going to address the University’s dress code policies.

Linda Standerford:

We expect our student employees to dress like students. That is completely acceptable as long as there is nothing too revealing, low cut, high cut or anything offensive.

Jackie Loghry:

There are a few events where we dress up. We also have staff apparel. We have a staff polo and a staff fleece. When we have an event we dress in our uniforms.

Stacey Stokes:

We do direct them on what to wear. We don’t allow casual clothing in the office. There are no T-shirts, there’s no screen printing on any of the shirts that are worn in the office. We do not expect them to dress up every day but to look nice, to look presentable, a step above casual.

Danny Smith:

We do supply the students with five work T-shirts, a pair of safety glasses, and a pair of gloves.

Travis Stokes:

We have an environmental services T-shirt that they all wear. And then, of course, our nifty name badge here.

Kathy Howell:

Whatever they’re wearing to class. We do say no hats. We ask them not to wear hats.

Jordan:

In summary, attire shall be discussed with your supervisor. However, the University does request that students dress appropriately for their position.

Kelsi:

Now let’s look at student employment transportation policies.

Monica McCollough:

We have two student positions which we require drivers. The first is our student ticket writer position. We have a more unique position with our safe rides employees and what these students do is drive throughout town and it’s similar to a taxi service.

Danny Smith:

Our student employees will drive anything; mostly our utility vehicles and mowers. On occasion they will be required to drive a pickup and trailer, anything that deals with our day to day activities.

Cindy Capps:

It’s important for us to get around to every department on campus to deliver mail. We go to some buildings twice a day with the heavier mail volume. We make sure we hit every department.

Monica McCollugh:

The first step is that within the student’s job description we need to clearly state that driving is a requirement for this position and so that’s the first step that it has to be a U.S. state issued driver’s license. The other thing is that we require all of our students to be mindful of the rules of the road. We really train our students to be superstars, be mindful of everything while they are out on the road and to know that they are in the public’s eye at that point. We train on the specific vehicles that the student will drive; certain vans. One of those vans is going to be a handicap accessible van. Some departments require students to drive a 15 passenger van and that’s rented through the university. Those vans do require a special certification called 15 Passenger Van Certification. Once they have completed that training they are proficient in how to maneuver such a large vehicle and they are good to go.

Kelsi:

In summary, transportation may be an expectation for some student employment positions. Student employees may be authorized to operate University vehicles within the city limits of Maryville to field study sites and University property within Nodaway County for the purpose of conducting university business provided they have a valid and appropriate driver’s license for the vehicle that they are operating and that they agree to drive the vehicle in a safe and prudent manner. Driver’s license requirements are in addition to any requirements, standards, suspensions or operating restrictions imposed by Missouri Law. Drivers are also required to have a valid driver’s license in their possession at all times. Students expected to operate a fifteen passenger vehicle must complete a training session with the environmental services department prior to operating the vehicle.

Jordan:

Now, let’s look at an array of additional campus policies.

Kelsi:

Student employees shall refer to the Northwest Student Handbook for details on policies and procedures for nondiscrimination and expected behavioral conduct in reference to: Americans with Disability Act Consensual Amorous Relationships Alcohol and Drug Policy Sexual Harassment Now we want to take a moment to discuss each of these issues.

Jordan:

The federal Americans with Disability Act provides a clear and comprehensive national mandate for the elimination of discrimination against individuals with disabilities. The law addresses employment, public service transportation, public accommodations and telecommunications. The individuals covered include persons who have a physical or mental condition substantially impairing “major life activities”.

Kelsi:

Consensual Amorous Relationships

Jordan:

Supervisors and student employees should be aware that consensual (i.e., both parties have consented) romantic and/or sexual amorous relationships with subordinate employees have the potential for adverse consequences. Even when both parties have consented to a relationship, there may be serious concerns about the conflicts of interest and unfair treatment of others.

Kelsi:

Alcohol and Drug Policy

Jordan:

Reporting to work under the influence of alcohol, illegal and/or controlled substances or the consumption of these products may result in immediate termination by the supervisor.

Kelsi:

Sexual Harassment

Jordan:

Any unwelcome attention of a sexual nature may be sexual harassment if it creates an intimidating, hostile or offensive environment or if it interferes with educational or work performance. Sexual harassment can be verbal, nonverbal, physical or written (including email). Sexual harassment is a violation of state and federal law as well as Northwest policy. If you feel you have been sexually harassed, report the problem to the Equal Employment Opportunity (EEO) Officer at 562-1128.

Kelsi:

Contact the Athletics Department for information regarding the Employment of a Student Athlete and NCAA Regulation.

Kelsi:

As in all employment, Student Employment has its own policies and procedures. These policies and procedures define the program and provide consistency on how the program operates. It is critical that student employees become aware of all policies and procedures. This module will cover the main policies and procedures. The student employment handbook, which can be found on-line, covers everything in detail. Let’s start with employment eligibility.

Jordan:

Eligibility to work is based on a student’s enrollment status. Policies and procedures apply to both undergraduate and graduate students, excluding graduate assistants.

A student must be enrolled in a minimum of six credit hours during any trimester to be eligible for employment. If enrollment falls below six credit hours, employment will be discontinued.

Kelsi:

Summer enrollment requirements are the same. A student employee shall be enrolled in a minimum of six credit hours during the summer trimester regardless of the session(s) of enrollment.

Jordan:

A student is eligible to work during the University intersession providing registration is complete for a minimum of six credit hours for the next trimester of coursework. If pre-registration is not complete, a letter of intent to enroll from the student shall be delivered to Student Employment.

Kelsi:

Students may work with five or fewer credit hours only when it is their last trimester of coursework. In this case written notification must be given to Student Employment prior to the beginning of the trimester.

Kelsi:

Now let’s look at hour limitations. A student employee may work up to 20 hours per week during the fall and spring trimesters. It is a maximum of 20 hours regardless of the number of positions that a student holds in the Student Employment Program. ARAMARK and off campus positions not affiliated with the Student Employment Program are not considered for the 20 hour a week limit unless the employee is an international student.

Jordan:

A student may work up to 20 hours a week during the summer trimester session they are enrolled and up to 40 hours a week during the summer trimester sessions they are not enrolled if they have been enrolled in a total of six credit hours in any session of the summer trimester. A student may also work up to 40 hours a week or the equivalent of an eight-hour workday during official University breaks. At no time shall a student be allowed to work over 40 hours per week.

Kelsi:

According to the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, international students are limited to a maximum of 20 hours per week during the fall and spring trimester and a maximum of 40 hours per week during the summer trimester sessions they are not enrolled and during official University breaks, regardless of the number of employers.

A student employee is not allowed to work during scheduled class time.

Jordan:

Each department or office may have additional policies. Work with your supervisor for full understanding of policies and procedures specific in your position.

Your schedule of work hours will vary depending which office or department you work for. Listen as a few supervisors explain how schedules work in their area.

Glenn Morrow:

We are open several hours during the day. We have to have someone at the library services desk each of those hours and so it takes quite a bit of scheduling to accommodate that.

We do in some areas of the library. Just as an example in the periodicals area we can allow some flexible schedules there. Supervisors and student employees should be aware that consensual (i.e., both parties have consented) romantic and/or sexual amorous relationships with subordinate employees have the potential for adverse consequences. Even when both parties have consented to a relationship, there may be serious concerns about the conflicts of interest and unfair treatment of others.

Kelsi:

Alcohol and Drug Policy

Jordan:

Reporting to work under the influence of alcohol, illegal and/or controlled substances or the consumption of these products may result in immediate termination by the supervisor.

Kelsi:

Sexual Harassment

Jordan:

Any unwelcome attention of a sexual nature may be sexual harassment if it creates an intimidating, hostile or offensive environment or if it interferes with educational or work performance. Sexual harassment can be verbal, nonverbal, physical or written (including email). Sexual harassment is a violation of state and federal law as well as Northwest policy. If you feel you have been sexually harassed, report the problem to the Equal Employment Opportunity (EEO) Officer at 562-1128.

Kelsi:

Contact the Athletics Department for information regarding the Employment of a Student Athlete and NCAA Regulation.

Kelsi:

As in all employment, Student Employment has its own policies and procedures. These policies and procedures define the program and provide consistency on how the program operates. It is critical that student employees become aware of all policies and procedures. This module will cover the main policies and procedures. The student employment handbook, which can be found on-line, covers everything in detail. Let’s start with employment eligibility.

Jordan:

Eligibility to work is based on a student’s enrollment status. Policies and procedures apply to both undergraduate and graduate students, excluding graduate assistants.

A student must be enrolled in a minimum of six credit hours during any trimester to be eligible for employment. If enrollment falls below six credit hours, employment will be discontinued.

Kelsi:

Summer enrollment requirements are the same. A student employee shall be enrolled in a minimum of six credit hours during the summer trimester regardless of the session(s) of enrollment.

Jordan:

A student is eligible to work during the University intersession providing registration is complete for a minimum of six credit hours for the next trimester of coursework. If pre-registration is not complete, a letter of intent to enroll from the student shall be delivered to Student Employment.

Kelsi:

Students may work with five or fewer credit hours only when it is their last trimester of coursework. In this case written notification must be given to Student Employment prior to the beginning of the trimester.

Kelsi:

Now let’s look at hour limitations. A student employee may work up to 20 hours per week during the fall and spring trimesters. It is a maximum of 20 hours regardless of the number of positions that a student holds in the Student Employment Program. ARAMARK and off campus positions not affiliated with the Student Employment Program are not considered for the 20 hour a week limit unless the employee is an international student.

Jordan:

A student may work up to 20 hours a week during the summer trimester session they are enrolled and up to 40 hours a week during the summer trimester sessions they are not enrolled if they have been enrolled in a total of six credit hours in any session of the summer trimester. A student may also work up to 40 hours a week or the equivalent of an eight-hour workday during official University breaks. At no time shall a student be allowed to work over 40 hours per week.

Kelsi:

According to the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, international students are limited to a maximum of 20 hours per week during the fall and spring trimester and a maximum of 40 hours per week during the summer trimester sessions they are not enrolled and during official University breaks, regardless of the number of employers.

A student employee is not allowed to work during scheduled class time.

Jordan:

Each department or office may have additional policies. Work with your supervisor for full understanding of policies and procedures specific in your position.

Kelsi:

Your schedule of work hours will vary depending which office or department you work for. Listen as a few supervisors explain how schedules work in their area.

Travis Stokes:

We understand that they are a student employee so they are a student first and so we work around their class schedules.

Stacy Stokes:

Our students work 8 to 5, Monday through Friday so we always have someone here in the office to answer the phones and cover the front counter. We set our schedule well in advance at the beginning of each trimester and it is set for the semester.

Glenn Morrow:

We are open several hours during the day. We have to have someone at the library services desk each of those hours and so it takes quite a bit of scheduling to accommodate that.

Danny Smith:

Student employees are allowed to work 20 hours a week or up to 20.

Jackie Loghry:

We allow them to set their own schedule as long as it’s when we’re open which is Monday through Friday, eight to five. They work ten hours each week in minimum two hour blocks a minimum of three days a week.

Linda Standerford:

Once I tell them how many hours they are going to work per week then I let them decide what hours they intend to work between the hours of eight to five, Monday through Friday.

Travis Stokes:

Yes. I do allow flexible schedules.

Linda Standerford:

Yes. We work with them. If they’ve got a week that they’ve got a lot of tests or maybe they’ve got a huge project we absolutely work with them.

Glenn Morrow:

We do in some areas of the library. Just as an example in the periodicals area we can allow some flexible schedules there. The majority of the areas, we can accommodate people except at the library services desk and we need someone there each hour as I’ve stated, so the flexibility is not so much there. That doesn’t mean they don’t have the option of switching out hours and trading hours but the desk has to be covered.

Linda Standerford:

Since our student employees are part time employees and generally they only work a few hours at a time, no, there is no need for a break.

Stacey Stokes:

We don’t have any scheduled breaks figured into the day but if someone were to need to go across the hall to the rest room, to get a snack, we will work with them on that but we don’t schedule that into the day.

Kelsi:

In summary, schedules are determined by the immediate supervisor and the student employee. Flexible schedules are offered to help accommodate students and their academic success. Any abuse of flexible scheduling may result in a discussion with the student employee.

Jordan:

A student shall be given a meal break if they are scheduled to work for an increment of eight hours or greater. Additional breaks shall be discussed with the supervisor. Remember, no breaks are paid.

Kelsi:

The university requires regular attendance and punctuality.

Linda Standerford:

We definitely expect good attendance and punctuality. That’s very important to the services we offer. So we do have a process in place if there is an employee that has issues with punctuality or tardiness.

Jackie Loghry:

We expect the students to work the 10 hours a week that they identify that they will be in the office so if they need to vary from those hours the policy is to contact the direct supervisor

Stacey Stokes:

When you are arriving to work you need to be here on time making certain that we have the front counter and the phone covered all times.

Travis Stokes:

We do expect our students to show up on time as a lot of our job is out in the field and if they tell us that they are going to be here at eight o’clock and they don’t show up until eight fifteen then we have just stood around waiting for them for fifteen minutes.

Linda Standerford:

If they need to be absent from their position I would expect them to let me know as soon as they can. If they are sick, obviously those are kind of last minute situations, but whenever possible we expect a notice as soon as we can get one.

Jackie Loghry:

They can call, email or text.

Stacy Stokes:

As soon as possible. Most advance notice that we can get is what we would prefer.

Travis Stokes:

If it’s a planned thing we would like at least a week’s notice for them.

Glenn Morrow:

We expect someone to be here and if they can’t be here and it’s something that is preplanned then we need to know in advance.

Danny Smith:

The best way to answer that is be responsible

Kelsi:

If prior communication is not feasible, communication shall be made as soon as possible. Excessive tardiness or absences may result in termination.

Jordan:

Now, we are going to address the University’s dress code policies.

Linda Standerford:

We expect our student employees to dress like students. That is completely acceptable as long as there is nothing too revealing, low cut, high cut or anything offensive.

Jackie Loghry:

There are a few events where we dress up. We also have staff apparel. We have a staff polo and a staff fleece. When we have an event we dress in our uniforms.

Stacey Stokes:

We do direct them on what to wear. We don’t allow casual clothing in the office. There are no T-shirts, there’s no screen printing on any of the shirts that are worn in the office. We do not expect them to dress up every day but to look nice, to look presentable, a step above casual.

Danny Smith:

We do supply the students with five work T-shirts, a pair of safety glasses, and a pair of gloves.

Travis Stokes:

We have an environmental services T-shirt that they all wear. And then, of course, our nifty name badge here.

Kathy Howell:

Whatever they’re wearing to class. We do say no hats. We ask them not to wear hats.

Jordan:

In summary, attire shall be discussed with your supervisor. However, the University does request that students dress appropriately for their position.

Kelsi:

Now let’s look at student employment transportation policies.

Monica McCollough:

We have two student positions which we require drivers. The first is our student ticket writer position. We have a more unique position with our safe rides employees and what these students do is drive throughout town and it’s similar to a taxi service.

Danny Smith:

Our student employees will drive anything; mostly our utility vehicles and mowers. On occasion they will be required to drive a pickup and trailer, anything that deals with our day to day activities.

Cindy Capps:

It’s important for us to get around to every department on campus to deliver mail. We go to some buildings twice a day with the heavier mail volume. We make sure we hit every department.

Monica McCollugh:

The first step is that within the student’s job description we need to clearly state that driving is a requirement for this position and so that’s the first step that it has to be a U.S. state issued driver’s license. The other thing is that we require all of our students to be mindful of the rules of the road. We really train our students to be superstars, be mindful of everything while they are out on the road and to know that they are in the public’s eye at that point. We train on the specific vehicles that the student will drive; certain vans. One of those vans is going to be a handicap accessible van. Some departments require students to drive a 15 passenger van and that’s rented through the university. Those vans do require a special certification called 15 Passenger Van Certification. Once they have completed that training they are proficient in how to maneuver such a large vehicle and they are good to go.

Kelsi:

In summary, transportation may be an expectation for some student employment positions. Student employees may be authorized to operate University vehicles within the city limits of Maryville to field study sites and University property within Nodaway County for the purpose of conducting university business provided they have a valid and appropriate driver’s license for the vehicle that they are operating and that they agree to drive the vehicle in a safe and prudent manner. Driver’s license requirements are in addition to any requirements, standards, suspensions or operating restrictions imposed by Missouri Law. Drivers are also required to have a valid driver’s license in their possession at all times. Students expected to operate a fifteen passenger vehicle must complete a training session with the environmental services department prior to operating the vehicle.

Jordan:

Now, let’s look at an array of additional campus policies.

Kelsi:

Student employees shall refer to the Northwest Student Handbook for details on policies and procedures for nondiscrimination and expected behavioral conduct in reference to: Americans with Disability Act Consensual Amorous Relationships Alcohol and Drug Policy Sexual Harassment Now we want to take a moment to discuss each of these issues.

Jordan:

The federal Americans with Disability Act provides a clear and comprehensive national mandate for the elimination of discrimination against individuals with disabilities. The law addresses employment, public service transportation, public accommodations and telecommunications. The individuals covered include persons who have a physical or mental condition substantially impairing “major life activities”.

Jordan:

Kelsi:

Sexual harassment can be verbal, nonverbal, physical or written (including email). Sexual harassment is a violation of state and federal law as well as Northwest policy. If you feel you have been sexually harassed, report the problem to the Equal Employment Opportunity (EEO) Officer at 562-1128.

If prior communication is not feasible, communication shall be made as soon as possible. Excessive tardiness or absences may result in termination.

Jordan:

Now, we are going to address the University’s dress code policies.

Linda Standerford:

We expect our student employees to dress like students. That is completely acceptable as long as there is nothing too revealing, low cut, high cut or anything offensive.

Jackie Loghry:

There are a few events where we dress up. We also have staff apparel. We have a staff polo and a staff fleece. When we have an event we dress in our uniforms.

Stacey Stokes:

We do direct them on what to wear. We don’t allow casual clothing in the office. There are no T-shirts, there’s no screen printing on any of the shirts that are worn in the office. We do not expect them to dress up every day but to look nice, to look presentable, a step above casual.

Danny Smith:

We do supply the students with five work T-shirts, a pair of safety glasses, and a pair of gloves.

Travis Stokes:

We have an environmental services T-shirt that they all wear. And then, of course, our nifty name badge here.

Kathy Howell:

Whatever they’re wearing to class. We do say no hats. We ask them not to wear hats.

Jordan:

In summary, attire shall be discussed with your supervisor. However, the University does request that students dress appropriately for their position.

Kelsi:

Now let’s look at student employment transportation policies.

Monica McCollough:

We have two student positions which we require drivers. The first is our student ticket writer position. We have a more unique position with our safe rides employees and what these students do is drive throughout town and it’s similar to a taxi service.

Danny Smith:

Our student employees will drive anything; mostly our utility vehicles and mowers. On occasion they will be required to drive a pickup and trailer, anything that deals with our day to day activities.

Cindy Capps:

It’s important for us to get around to every department on campus to deliver mail. We go to some buildings twice a day with the heavier mail volume. We make sure we hit every department.

Monica McCollugh:

The first step is that within the student’s job description we need to clearly state that driving is a requirement for this position and so that’s the first step that it has to be a U.S. state issued driver’s license. The other thing is that we require all of our students to be mindful of the rules of the road. We really train our students to be superstars, be mindful of everything while they are out on the road and to know that they are in the public’s eye at that point. We train on the specific vehicles that the student will drive; certain vans. One of those vans is going to be a handicap accessible van. Some departments require students to drive a 15 passenger van and that’s rented through the university. Those vans do require a special certification called 15 Passenger Van Certification. Once they have completed that training they are proficient in how to maneuver such a large vehicle and they are good to go.

Kelsi:

In summary, transportation may be an expectation for some student employment positions. Student employees may be authorized to operate University vehicles within the city limits of Maryville to field study sites and University property within Nodaway County for the purpose of conducting university business provided they have a valid and appropriate driver’s license for the vehicle that they are operating and that they agree to drive the vehicle in a safe and prudent manner. Driver’s license requirements are in addition to any requirements, standards, suspensions or operating restrictions imposed by Missouri Law. Drivers are also required to have a valid driver’s license in their possession at all times. Students expected to operate a fifteen passenger vehicle must complete a training session with the environmental services department prior to operating the vehicle.

Jordan:

Now, let’s look at an array of additional campus policies.

Kelsi:

Student employees shall refer to the Northwest Student Handbook for details on policies and procedures for nondiscrimination and expected behavioral conduct in reference to: Americans with Disability Act Consensual Amorous Relationships Alcohol and Drug Policy Sexual Harassment Now we want to take a moment to discuss each of these issues.

Jordan:

The federal Americans with Disability Act provides a clear and comprehensive national mandate for the elimination of discrimination against individuals with disabilities. The law addresses employment, public service transportation, public accommodations and telecommunications. The individuals covered include persons who have a physical or mental condition substantially impairing “major life activities”.

Kelsi:

Consensual Amorous Relationships

Jordan:

Supervisors and student employees should be aware that consensual (i.e., both parties have consented) romantic and/or sexual amorous relationships with subordinate employees have the potential for adverse consequences. Even when both parties have consented to a relationship, there may be serious concerns about the conflicts of interest and unfair treatment of others.

Kelsi:

Alcohol and Drug Policy

Jordan:

Reporting to work under the influence of alcohol, illegal and/or controlled substances or the consumption of these products may result in immediate termination by the supervisor.

Kelsi:

Sexual Harassment

Jordan:

Any unwelcome attention of a sexual nature may be sexual harassment if it creates an intimidating, hostile or offensive environment or if it interferes with educational or work performance. Sexual harassment can be verbal, nonverbal, physical or written (including email). Sexual harassment is a violation of state and federal law as well as Northwest policy. If you feel you have been sexually harassed, report the problem to the Equal Employment Opportunity (EEO) Officer at 562-1128.

Kelsi:

Contact the Athletics Department for information regarding the Employment of a Student Athlete and NCAA Regulation.

Kelsi:

As in all employment, Student Employment has its own policies and procedures. These policies and procedures define the program and provide consistency on how the program operates. It is critical that student employees become aware of all policies and procedures. This module will cover the main policies and procedures. The student employment handbook, which can be found on-line, covers everything in detail. Let’s start with employment eligibility.

Jordan:

Eligibility to work is based on a student’s enrollment status. Policies and procedures apply to both undergraduate and graduate students, excluding graduate assistants.

A student must be enrolled in a minimum of six credit hours during any trimester to be eligible for employment. If enrollment falls below six credit hours, employment will be discontinued.

Kelsi:

Summer enrollment requirements are the same. A student employee shall be enrolled in a minimum of six credit hours during the summer trimester regardless of the session(s) of enrollment.

Jordan:

A student is eligible to work during the University intersession providing registration is complete for a minimum of six credit hours for the next trimester of coursework. If pre-registration is not complete, a letter of intent to enroll from the student shall be delivered to Student Employment.

Kelsi:

Students may work with five or fewer credit hours only when it is their last trimester of coursework. In this case written notification must be given to Student Employment prior to the beginning of the trimester.

Kelsi:

Now let’s look at hour limitations. A student employee may work up to 20 hours per week during the fall and spring trimesters. It is a maximum of 20 hours regardless of the number of positions that a student holds in the Student Employment Program. ARAMARK and off campus positions not affiliated with the Student Employment Program are not considered for the 20 hour a week limit unless the employee is an international student.

Jordan:

A student may work up to 20 hours a week during the summer trimester session they are enrolled and up to 40 hours a week during the summer trimester sessions they are not enrolled if they have been enrolled in a total of six credit hours in any session of the summer trimester. A student may also work up to 40 hours a week or the equivalent of an eight-hour workday during official University breaks. At no time shall a student be allowed to work over 40 hours per week.

Kelsi:

According to the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, international students are limited to a maximum of 20 hours per week during the fall and spring trimester and a maximum of 40 hours per week during the summer trimester sessions they are not enrolled and during official University breaks, regardless of the number of employers.

A student employee is not allowed to work during scheduled class time.

Jordan:

Each department or office may have additional policies. Work with your supervisor for full understanding of policies and procedures specific in your position.

Kelsi:

Your schedule of work hours will vary depending which office or department you work for. Listen as a few supervisors explain how schedules work in their area.

Travis Stokes:

We understand that they are a student employee so they are a student first and so we work around their class schedules.

Stacy Stokes:

Our students work 8 to 5, Monday through Friday so we always have someone here in the office to answer the phones and cover the front counter. We set our schedule well in advance at the beginning of each trimester and it is set for the semester.

Glenn Morrow:

We are open several hours during the day. We have to have someone at the library services desk each of those hours and so it takes quite a bit of scheduling to accommodate that.

Danny Smith:

Student employees are allowed to work 20 hours a week or up to 20.

Jackie Loghry:

We allow them to set their own schedule as long as it’s when we’re open which is Monday through Friday, eight to five. They work ten hours each week in minimum two hour blocks a minimum of three days a week.

Linda Standerford:

Once I tell them how many hours they are going to work per week then I let them decide what hours they intend to work between the hours of eight to five, Monday through Friday.

Travis Stokes:

Yes. I do allow flexible schedules.

Linda Standerford:

Yes. We work with them. If they’ve got a week that they’ve got a lot of tests or maybe they’ve got a huge project we absolutely work with them.

Glenn Morrow:

We do in some areas of the library. Just as an example in the periodicals area we can allow some flexible schedules there. The majority of the areas, we can accommodate people except at the library services desk and we need someone there each hour as I’ve stated, so the flexibility is not so much there. That doesn’t mean they don’t have the option of switching out hours and trading hours but the desk has to be covered.

Linda Standerford:

Since our student employees are part time employees and generally they only work a few hours at a time, no, there is no need for a break.

Stacey Stokes:

We don’t have any scheduled breaks figured into the day but if someone were to need to go across the hall to the rest room, to get a snack, we will work with them on that but we don’t schedule that into the day.

Kelsi:

In summary, schedules are determined by the immediate supervisor and the student employee. Flexible schedules are offered to help accommodate students and their academic success. Any abuse of flexible scheduling may result in a discussion with the student employee.

Jordan:

A student shall be given a meal break if they are scheduled to work for an increment of eight hours or greater. Additional breaks shall be discussed with the supervisor. Remember, no breaks are paid.

Kelsi:

The university requires regular attendance and punctuality.

Linda Standerford:

We definitely expect good attendance and punctuality. That’s very important to the services we offer. So we do have a process in place if there is an employee that has issues with punctuality or tardiness.

Jackie Loghry:

We expect the students to work the 10 hours a week that they identify that they will be in the office so if they need to vary from those hours the policy is to contact the direct supervisor

Stacey Stokes:

When you are arriving to work you need to be here on time making certain that we have the front counter and the phone covered all times.

Travis Stokes:

We do expect our students to show up on time as a lot of our job is out in the field and if they tell us that they are going to be here at eight o’clock and they don’t show up until eight fifteen then we have just stood around waiting for them for fifteen minutes.

Linda Standerford:

If they need to be absent from their position I would expect them to let me know as soon as they can. If they are sick, obviously those are kind of last minute situations, but whenever possible we expect a notice as soon as we can get one.

Jackie Loghry:

They can call, email or text.

Stacy Stokes:

As soon as possible. Most advance notice that we can get is what we would prefer.

Travis Stokes:

If it’s a planned thing we would like at least a week’s notice for them.

Glenn Morrow:

We expect someone to be here and if they can’t be here and it’s something that is preplanned then we need to know in advance.

Danny Smith:

The best way to answer that is be responsible

Kelsi:

If prior communication is not feasible, communication shall be made as soon as possible. Excessive tardiness or absences may result in termination.

Linda Standerford:

We expect our student employees to dress like students. That is completely acceptable as long as there is nothing too revealing, low cut, high cut or anything offensive.

Jackie Loghry:

There are a few events where we dress up. We also have staff apparel. We have a staff polo and a staff fleece. When we have an event we dress in our uniforms.

Stacey Stokes:

We do direct them on what to wear. We don’t allow casual clothing in the office. There are no T-shirts, there’s no screen printing on any of the shirts that are worn in the office. We do not expect them to dress up every day but to look nice, to look presentable, a step above casual.

Whatever they’re wearing to class. We do say no hats. We ask them not to wear hats.
